Rationalizing the denominator, we get
\[\frac{2}{\sqrt{n} + \sqrt{n + 2}} = \frac{2 (\sqrt{n + 2} - \sqrt{n})}{(\sqrt{n + 2} + \sqrt{n})(\sqrt{n + 2} - \sqrt{n})} = \frac{2 (\sqrt{n + 2} - \sqrt{n})}{(n + 2) - n} = \sqrt{n + 2} - \sqrt{n}.\]Therefore,
\begin{align*}
\sum_{n = 1}^{99} \frac{2}{\sqrt{n} + \sqrt{n + 2}} &= \sum_{n = 1}^{99} (\sqrt{n + 2} - \sqrt{n}) \\
&= (\sqrt{3} - 1) + (\sqrt{4} - \sqrt{2}) + (\sqrt{5} - \sqrt{3}) + \dots + (\sqrt{100} - \sqrt{98}) + (\sqrt{101} - \sqrt{99}) \\
&= \sqrt{100} + \sqrt{101} - 1 - \sqrt{2} \\
&= \boxed{\sqrt{101} - \sqrt{2} + 9}.
\end{align*}
